### **Case Study: Headspace — From Mindfulness to Management**

Headspace is not a meditation app. It’s a productivity enhancer in monk robes.

In 2010, Andy Puddicombe and Rich Pierson launched Headspace as a way to help people “unclutter the mind.” By 2023, it had raised over $1 billion in funding and was valued at $2.3 billion. Its core offering — 10-minute guided meditations — is framed as a path to inner peace. But the real product is not mindfulness. It’s **predictable attention**.

Headspace’s business model is built on a simple insight: if you can train people to be calmer, you can make them more efficient. And if you can sell that training to corporations, you can make them more profitable.

In 2017, Headspace launched its **Enterprise** division. Now, companies like Microsoft, Google, and Deloitte pay premium rates to give their employees “mindfulness tools” — as if the same app that helps you fall asleep is the same one that helps you stay awake at your desk for 12 hours. The language is soothing. The outcome is optimized labor.

Headspace doesn’t just help people meditate — it helps them **perform better under pressure**. It doesn’t just help you focus — it helps you **stay focused on the job**. And in doing so, it turns the very act of calming the mind into a form of **quiet compliance**.

The irony is almost too perfect: the same app that tells you to “breathe and let go” is now being used to keep you breathing and going — all day, every day.

- **The profit** (enterprise licensing, corporate partnerships)

### **Case Study: Portland’s Digital Wellness Initiative — A Public Health Campaign Funded by Private Mindfulness Vendors**

In 2022, the city of Portland launched its **Digital Wellness for All** initiative — a public health campaign framed as a response to rising anxiety, burnout, and “digital fatigue” among its residents. The messaging was soft, the branding was pastel, and the press release was filled with talk of “reclaiming attention” and “building a healthier relationship with technology.”

The initiative was quietly funded through a **public-private partnership** with major players in the wellness and productivity space: Headspace, Calm, and a local mindfulness startup with ties to Silicon Valley venture capital. The city’s health department, in collaboration with a “wellness task force” made up of app developers and corporate HR consultants, began distributing free subscriptions to mindfulness apps to public school teachers, city workers, and even first responders — all in the name of “digital wellness.”

The language was altruistic. The outcome was infrastructure.

The real goal wasn’t to help people unplug — it was to **normalize the idea that mindfulness is a public good**. And once that line is drawn in the sand, it becomes just one more service that can be outsourced, privatized, and scaled.

By the time the program was fully rolled out, the city had **allocated over $1.2 million in public funds** to mindfulness vendors — all while the city’s schools were still struggling to fund basic mental health services. The same tools that were once sold as lifestyle upgrades were now being rebranded as **essential infrastructure**, and the same people who once sold distraction were now selling its cure — to the public, with public money.

The city council meeting minutes were written in **Calm-app pastels**, the PowerPoint slides were filled with **mantra-driven KPIs**, and the only dissenting voice in the room was the one asking: *Who gets to decide what “wellness” looks like?*
